metadata.title: Circle
metadata.subject: Mathematics
metadata.description: Circumference, radius, diameter, arc, central angle, measure of arc

preAssessment.question: What is the relationship between circumference and diameter of a circle?
What is the circumference of a circle with diameter 14 cm? (Use Ï€ = 22/7)
The arc that is smaller than a semicircle is called _____.
The measure of a semicircular arc is _____.
The radius of a circular garden is 56 m. At â‚¹40 per metre for 4 rounds, what is the fencing cost? (Ï€=22/7)

concepts.title: Circumference and Ï€ (Pi)
concepts.content: The ratio of the circumference of any circle to its diameter is a constant called Ï€ (pi). Ï€ â‰ˆ 22/7 â‰ˆ 3.14. It is irrational (not a rational number). If radius is r and diameter is d, then circumference c = Ï€d = 2Ï€r.

examples.text: Bangle: circumference 19cm, diameter 6cm, ratio = 3.16 â‰ˆ Ï€
Circular dish: ratio of circumference to diameter â‰ˆ 3.14
c = Ï€d = 22/7 Ã— 14 = 44 cm (for diameter 14cm)
c = 2Ï€r = 2 Ã— 22/7 Ã— 35 = 220 cm (for radius 35cm)

keyPoints: c/d = Ï€ for any circle
Ï€ â‰ˆ 22/7 â‰ˆ 3.14 (irrational number)
Circumference c = Ï€d = 2Ï€r
If Ï€ value not given, use 22/7
Ï€ was proved irrational by great mathematicians
concepts.funFact: ğŸŒ Archimedes calculated Ï€ to be between 3 10/71 and 3 1/7 over 2200 years ago â€” and we still use 22/7 today!

concepts.title: Calculating Circumference
concepts.content: Use c = Ï€d when diameter is given, or c = 2Ï€r when radius is given. To find radius from circumference: r = c/(2Ï€). To find diameter from circumference: d = c/Ï€. Always check units â€” convert km to m when needed.

examples.text: Diameter 14cm: c = 22/7 Ã— 14 = 44 cm
Radius 35cm: c = 2 Ã— 22/7 Ã— 35 = 220 cm
Bus wheel d=0.7m: c=2.2m; 22km = 22000m â†’ 10000 rotations

keyPoints: c = Ï€d (use when diameter is given)
c = 2Ï€r (use when radius is given)
r = c/(2Ï€) (find radius from circumference)
d = c/Ï€ (find diameter from circumference)
Convert all units before calculating
concepts.funFact: ğŸš² A bicycle wheel of diameter 70cm travels 2.2m per rotation â€” you can calculate how many rotations for any journey!

concepts.title: Arc, Chord and Types of Arcs
concepts.content: A chord divides a circle into two arcs. The smaller arc is the minor arc and the larger is the major arc. If two arcs together make a complete circle, they are corresponding arcs. A diameter creates two equal semicircular arcs, each measuring 180Â°.

examples.text: Chord AB divides circle: smaller = minor arc AXB, larger = major arc AYB
Bangle breaks at A and B: each piece is an arc
Diameter RT: two equal semicircular arcs, each 180Â°
Arc AXB and arc AYB are corresponding arcs (together = complete circle)

keyPoints: Chord divides circle into two arcs
Minor arc: smaller arc
Major arc: larger arc
Corresponding arcs: two arcs that together form a complete circle
Diameter creates two equal semicircular arcs of 180Â° each
concepts.funFact: ğŸ’ When a bangle breaks, each piece is an arc! The two pieces together form the complete circle.

concepts.title: Central Angle and Measure of Arc
concepts.content: A central angle is an angle whose vertex is the centre of the circle. The measure of an arc equals the measure of its corresponding central angle. Measure of major arc = 360Â° - measure of minor arc. A complete circle measures 360Â°. Semicircular arc = 180Â°.

examples.text: âˆ AOQ = 70Â° â†’ minor arc AYQ measures 70Â°
Major arc AXQ = 360Â° - 70Â° = 290Â°
m(arc AXB) = 120Â° â†’ m(arc AYB) = 360Â° - 120Â° = 240Â°
Complete circle = 360Â°; Semicircle = 180Â°

keyPoints: Central angle: vertex at centre of circle
Measure of minor arc = corresponding central angle
Measure of major arc = 360Â° - minor arc measure
Complete circle = 360Â°
Semicircular arc = 180Â°
concepts.funFact: ğŸŒ The 360Â° circle is ancient â€” Babylonian astronomers used it 4000 years ago because 360 has many divisors!
concepts.textbookRef: Page 78: Central Angle and Arc Measure

concepts.title: Real-world Applications
concepts.content: Circles appear everywhere: fencing circular gardens (circumference Ã— number of rounds), wheel rotations (distance Ã· circumference), cost calculations. For these problems, find the circumference first, then apply the given rate or number of rounds.

examples.text: Garden r=56m: c=352m; 4 rounds = 1408m; cost at â‚¹40/m = â‚¹56,320
Bus wheel d=0.7m: c=2.2m; distance 22km=22000m; rotations=10000
Bullock cart wheel d=1.4m: c=4.4m; distance 1.1km=1100m; rotations=250
Circular plot r=7.7m: 3 rounds fencing at â‚¹50/m: cost=â‚¹7,260

keyPoints: Fencing cost = circumference Ã— number of rounds Ã— cost per metre
Rotations = total distance Ã· circumference
Convert all distances to same units before dividing
1 rotation = 1 circumference of the wheel
Find circumference first before solving application problems
concepts.funFact: ğŸš² A bicycle wheel of diameter 0.7m completes exactly 10,000 rotations to travel 22 km â€” pure mathematics in motion!

test.question: The diameter of a circle is 14 cm. What is its circumference? (Ï€ = 22/7)
The radius of a circle is 35 cm. What is its circumference? (Ï€ = 22/7)
If circumference is 176 cm, what is the radius? (Ï€ = 22/7)
Arc AXB and arc AYB are corresponding arcs. m(arc AXB) = 120Â°. What is m(arc AYB)?
test.explanation: Measure of major arc = 360Â° - minor arc = 360Â° - 120Â° = 240Â°

test.question: The measure of a minor arc is 110Â°. What is the measure of the major arc PYQ?
A wheel has diameter 0.7 m. How many rotations to travel 22 km?
The circumference of a circle is 62.80 cm. What is its diameter? (Ï€ = 3.14)
A central angle of 70Â° corresponds to a minor arc. What is the measure of this arc?
test.explanation: The measure of a minor arc equals its corresponding central angle. So the arc measures 70Â°.

test.question: The circumference of a circle is 198 cm. What is its radius? (Ï€ = 22/7)
The radius of a circular garden is 56 m. What is the cost of 4-round fencing at â‚¹40/m? (Ï€=22/7)

keyConcepts: Minor arc < semicircle; Major arc > semicircle
Corresponding arcs: two arcs forming a complete circle
Measure of minor arc = corresponding central angle
Measure of major arc = 360Â° - minor arc
commonMisconceptions: Ï€ = 22/7 exactly â€” FALSE, 22/7 is an approximation; Ï€ is irrational
Circumference = 2Ï€d â€” FALSE, it's 2Ï€r or Ï€d (not both)
Major arc measure = 360Â° - major arc â€” FALSE, it's 360Â° - MINOR arc
All chords are diameters â€” FALSE, diameter is the longest chord only
realWorldExamples: Circular garden fencing: circumference Ã— rounds Ã— cost per metre
Wheel rotations: total distance Ã· circumference
Bangle measurement: use thread to measure circumference
Bicycle wheel: calculate journey distance from rotations
Circular plate: find circumference to estimate edge length

formulas.explanation: Number of wheel rotations for a given distance

interactiveElement.title: Build the Formula!
interactiveElement.description: Arrange the pieces to form the correct mathematical expression.

data.formula: Area of Circle = Ï€ Ã— rÂ²
data.explanation: The area of a circle is pi times the radius squared.

qaCards.answer: Measure of major arc = 360Â° - minor arc = 360Â° - 120Â° = 240Â°

longAnswers.question: The diameter of a circle is 14 cm. What is its circumference? (Ï€ = 22/7)
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The circumference of a circle is the total distance around its edge. To calculate the circumference when the diameter is given, we use the formula c = Ï€d. Substituting the given values, we get c = (22/7) Ã— 14. Simplifying this by dividing 14 by 7 gives 2, and 22 Ã— 2 equals 44 cm. Therefore, the circumference of the circle is 44 cm.
keyPoints: Circumference is the total boundary distance of a circle.
The formula used is c = Ï€d.
Substituting d = 14 and Ï€ = 22/7 gives (22/7) Ã— 14.
The final calculated circumference is 44 cm.

longAnswers.question: The radius of a circle is 35 cm. What is its circumference? (Ï€ = 22/7)
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The circumference can be calculated using the circle's radius with the formula c = 2Ï€r. In this problem, the radius (r) is given as 35 cm and Ï€ is taken as 22/7. Plugging these values into the formula gives c = 2 Ã— (22/7) Ã— 35. Dividing 35 by 7 gives 5, and multiplying 2 Ã— 22 Ã— 5 results in 220 cm. This means the total distance around the circle is 220 cm.
keyPoints: Use the formula c = 2Ï€r when the radius is known.
Substitute r = 35 and Ï€ = 22/7 into the equation.
Simplify the expression: 2 Ã— (22/7) Ã— 35 = 220.
The circumference of the given circle is 220 cm.

longAnswers.question: If circumference is 176 cm, what is the radius? (Ï€ = 22/7)
longAnswers.modelAnswer: To find the radius of a circle when its circumference is known, we rearrange the formula c = 2Ï€r. This gives us r = c / (2Ï€). Substituting the given circumference of 176 cm and Ï€ = 22/7, the equation becomes 176 = 2 Ã— (22/7) Ã— r. Solving for r, we multiply 176 by 7 and divide by 44 (which is 2 Ã— 22). This calculation yields a radius of 28 cm.
keyPoints: The relationship between circumference and radius is c = 2Ï€r.
Substitute the known circumference (176 cm) into the formula.
Rearrange the equation to solve for the unknown radius (r).
The calculated radius is 28 cm.

longAnswers.question: Arc AXB and arc AYB are corresponding arcs. m(arc AXB) = 120Â°. What is m(arc AYB)?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: Corresponding arcs are two arcs that together form a complete circle. The total measure of a complete circle is always 360Â°. To find the measure of the major arc AYB, we must subtract the measure of the minor arc AXB from 360Â°. Since m(arc AXB) is 120Â°, we calculate 360Â° - 120Â°, which equals 240Â°. Thus, the measure of the corresponding major arc AYB is 240Â°.
keyPoints: Corresponding arcs together make a full circle measuring 360Â°.
The measure of a major arc is 360Â° minus the measure of its corresponding minor arc.
Subtract the given minor arc measure (120Â°) from 360Â°.
The measure of the major arc AYB is 240Â°.

longAnswers.question: The measure of a minor arc is 110Â°. What is the measure of the major arc PYQ?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: A minor arc and its corresponding major arc together complete a full circle, which measures 360Â°. The measure of a major arc is calculated by subtracting the measure of the minor arc from 360Â°. In this case, the minor arc measures 110Â°. Subtracting 110Â° from 360Â° yields 250Â°. Therefore, the measure of the major arc PYQ is 250Â°.
keyPoints: A full circle always measures 360 degrees.
Major arc measure = 360Â° - minor arc measure.
Substitute the minor arc value: 360Â° - 110Â°.
The resulting measure for the major arc PYQ is 250Â°.

longAnswers.question: A wheel has diameter 0.7 m. How many rotations to travel 22 km?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The distance a wheel covers in one rotation is exactly equal to its circumference. First, we find the circumference using c = Ï€d, which gives (22/7) Ã— 0.7 = 2.2 meters. Next, we convert the total distance of 22 km into meters, resulting in 22,000 meters. To find the number of rotations, we divide the total distance by the circumference (22,000 Ã· 2.2). This calculation shows that the wheel must make 10,000 rotations to cover the entire distance.
keyPoints: One full rotation of a wheel equals its circumference.
Calculate the circumference: c = Ï€d = (22/7) Ã— 0.7 = 2.2 m.
Convert the total travel distance to meters: 22 km = 22,000 m.
Number of rotations = Total distance Ã· Circumference.
The wheel requires 10,000 rotations to travel 22 km.
